That's why they removed red pot from the game.  Riven is still playable (in low to moderate elo), but not dominant and not cheesy in early laning.

I don't get what's the big deal about an AD scaling shield, anyway.  Most other champs with a shield have AP scaling on the shield and AP scaling on their damage, so they *also* get shields and damage with the same stat.  If the ratio was too high, that would be a problem, but IIRC it's not particularly high at all.

All shields also scale with the defensive stats of the recipient, but Riven's is self only, so she can't get that benefit unless she builds bruiser herself.  (Compare, say, Orianna + Malphite.)

Ap champs have no good way of sustain, Ad champs have atleast 1 lifesteal item in their corebuilt, which is a nother defense source that scales with offense.
A riven with BT rush will be nearly impossible to kill 1v1 if ahead with the combination of lifesteal and shield.

Also, it's not only the shield but the kit around, Riven got 2 aoe hard ccs and a fuckload of free mobillity, which makes her damn slippery.
Compared to Ap-champs with shields, Diana is all-in, she has no defensive mobillity, she needs the survivabillity granted by the shield - and she's known for snowballing in both directions aswell.
Ekko's shield is only a minor part, as he usually stuns you for the time his shield is up.
The other ap-scaleing shields can be cast on allys, they are utillity tools and the champions that have them pay for it with rather low mobillity and compareable low damage.
Also, most utillity mages tend to stay ahead if they get ahead...

Shields scaleing with offensive stats always is rather snowbally, so are ad-casters in general due itemisation, and so is the combination of high mobillity and high damage.
In Riven, all of that comes together...

With AP champions, the offensive scaling shield is less of a problem because the champions with those shields usually have less damage than other burst or sustain mages.

But Most importantly is that Autoattacks don't have an AP ratio, so AP is an inherently less offensive stat than AD unless the champion is specifically build around using it as such (looking at you {{champion:268}}  and {{champion:69}} )

> [{quoted}](name=Partholonian,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=QGlGjOyq,comment-id=0008000000000001000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2015-07-25T02:46:34.496+0000)
>
> I don't get what's the big deal about an AD scaling shield, anyway.  

An AD Scaling Shield is absolutely insane. It allows a champion that's already snowballing to snowball even harder and be rewarded for building glass cannon, on a stat that's already quite versatile. AD is stronger at taking objectives, stronger at clearing jungle, and more reliable in a fight because you get all of that damage on your auto attacks in addition to any spell scaling on AD.

By comparison, AP only adds 40% to damage on structures, adds 6% to your auto attacks IF YOU GET THE SPELLBLADE MASTERY and otherwise needs {{item:3115}} or {{item:3100}} to apply an AP Ratio (which is 15% and 50% scaling respectively) when auto attacking and if you can't cast spells, the stat is essentially worthless. Mages have utility because unlike AD which is reliable no matter what you are doing, AP requires you to be constantly casting spells in order to be effective.
